data.contentText: It was new for us to code as a team. Write code in a way that others would understand as well as work with each other's code. We had to learn a new way to think about components and all the use cases they could have.

data.buttonText: What skills did you improve the most?
data.contentText: Working according good practices, write clean code, working in team, reading and understanding other people code, many tech things.

data.buttonText: How was your experience working as a team?
data.contentText: I think it was a great experience of how our team grew together maybe we started a little shy but went on to collaborate excellently, helping each other and making big decisions together. We managed to keep our meetings regular and fun.

data.buttonText: The happiest and the saddest thing that happened during academy.
data.contentText: Happiest moments were when after struggling for a while I could solve all things, so this gave me more self confidence.  Happiest things- the team, that became my second family. Saddest thing, that all thing has its ending and the question- what's next? Somehow I'll have to find something to fill this void that will come after graduating from the academy.

data.buttonText: What would you change in the academy?
data.contentText: My personal opinion, since the quality of this academy was exceptional, I would like to see this academy more than once a year to help other fresh developers gain some hands-on experience of what it is like to be a front-end developer.

data.buttonText: Did the project fulfill your expectations?
data.contentText: Definitely, we had an opportunity to simulate a real-life project, with all its nuance and problems learning good practices and getting some hands-on experience. Which is invaluable for junior developers like us.

data.buttonText: How would you define your team's mentor?
data.contentText: The best mentor ever! He is so honest, patient and dedicated. Helps everyone, patiently answers all questions, doesn't spare advices.
